comments:
When i try to run an application out of eclipse in Debug mode, the application
often won't start but the eclipse progress list is empty if there are other
applications currently running. 
In the Debug window I often just see ... instead of the application name that
should start. It sometimes helps to select the ... entry or the other
applications and terminate them and remove them from the Debug window, then some
tasks show up in the progress window, and the application I wanted to start is
executed. It looks like there is some blocking or deadlocks, that prevent the
eclipse internal tasks to be executed. 
This only happens if HyperThreading is activated.

Regards,

 - Bernd Rosstauscher

I'm running a hyper-threaded Intel box too and have not seen this. What other 
tasks are running when you try to launch. Do you have the option on to "build 
before launching"?

Th option "Build (if required) before launching" is activated. Project Settings
are "Build Automatically".

We develop a client server application. First I start the server. After that I
start the Client. The server keeps running. The client is stopped and restarted
as I continue developing. Often the client won't start. Sometimes in the Debug
box "..." is displayed. Sometimes it helps to remove that entry, sometimes it
helps to stop the server and remove all, and sometimes only restarting eclipse
helps. When you deactivate HyperThreading in the Bios options of the PC this
does not occure.

We are a team of 20 Software Developers all using the same machines. Dell
Precision 370. It occures on all of them. Perhaps it happens only on this machines?

Hope this helps.

Can you produce/attach a thread dump so we can see what is going on in the VM 
when you experience the "deadlock" (i.e. launch Eclispe with a DOS console, 
and do a CTRL-Break to generate the thread dump).

Hello there,
sorry for the late response.
Ok I produced you a thread dump. As I did this, I tried to run the Client, but
it does not start, the Open Type feature does not show any classes, the search
does not find anything, ... Something seems to be blocked.
Here you go. I hope this helps you to locate the problem.

Tell me if I can help in some other way.

Regards,

 - Bernd Rosstauscher


------------------------------

What version/build of Eclipse is being used here?

Hello there 
I use Eclipse 3.1 Milestone 6
Build id: I20050219-1500

Regards,

  - Bernd Rosstauscher

Correction: that build id matches 3.1 M5, not M6.

The stack is strange - a job is waiting for a UI job, but there are no other
jobs running.  By any chance does your error log show anything around the time
of the failure? (workspace/.metadata/.log).
*poke*  Anything?

Screenshot showing the problem

Hi there,
ok my mistake. Now I started up the eclipse 3.1M6 with Build id: I20050401-1645
The problems are still occuring. I checked the log and there are no exceptions
in it.

I stopped my application but it is still in the debug view. Search does not
work, Task List ist no updated and all other jobs seam to be blocked.

See also the screenshot I attached.
If I select there the Client in the debug view and remove it by pressing the
delete key then the jobs blocked in the list continue and everything is working
again.

Very strange.  Just to confirm, are you only seeing this problem when launching
an application in debug mode? Do you get hangs or deadlocks at other times?

This happens only after some timed. After I have started and terminated my
client a few times. Either eclipse gets blocked when I want to start my client
application again, or directly after I terminated my client application, then
the client stays in the debug view. I never start it normally, always in debug
mode. But I can try it out if this happens too when I start it normally.

I have never experienced deadlocks during other activities such as rebuilding
the workspace or normal programming tasks. But of course if eclipse is blocked
due to a "hanging" Client in the debug view, then other features are impacted
too. Search does not work, "Automatic Compiling" does not work, ... 
But I think this is only because then the jobmanager is blocked.

Created an attachment (id=21054)
Plugin with job debugging

This plugin adds an action that dumps diagnostic information about the state of
the job scheduler. To install:
1) Shutdown Eclipse
2) Drop this plugin into the eclipse/plugins directory
3) Restart with -clean command line argument, and with java.exe instead of
javaw.exe. Example:

eclipse -clean -vm d:\jre\bin\java.exe

Then when you get into this state, open the "Job" menu and click "Dump Job
Information".  Attach that ouput to this bug.

Notes for myself:

 - None of the running jobs in the trace use a scheduling rule
 - Many of the waiting jobs don't use a scheduling rule
 - Two reasons for a job to be in a waiting state:
     1) Blocked on a scheduling rule
     2) A worker thread has not come along to service it
 - In the stack dump there are no idle Worker threads

The problem for most waiting jobs seems to be starvation rather than deadlock. 
For some reason the worker pool is not spawning sufficient threads to service
the backlog of waiting jobs.
*** Bug 93404 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bernd, if/when you upgrade to 3.1 M7, I have created an instrumented version of
the Eclipse runtime.  With this instrumented version, if you run the same "Dump
Job Information" action as you did on Friday, it will print out more detailed
information about the internal state.  I'm hoping this will yield more clues
about why those jobs are never running.  If necessary, I can create an
instrumented version of a previous milestone (such as M6) with the same information.

The patch is found here:

http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-core-home/downloads/patches/bug_91853/org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.0.jar

To install, just drop this JAR file in the eclipse/plugins directory, replacing
the JAR file of the same name (create a copy of the old one if you like).

We are getting very close to the final 3.1 release so I am keen on getting this
one solved!

Thanks Bernd, this is exactly the information I was looking for.  I had a theory
that one of my counters (busyThreads, sleepingThreads, etc), was becoming
invalid, and this output proves it. "numThreads" is correct, and
"sleepingThreads" also appears to be correct since two jobs are running.
However, "busyThreads" should be 2 instead of 1.  This is the source of the
livelock. I have reviewed every line of this code, but I'll be reviewing it
again with this information to see if I can find the source of the problem.
Still never reproduced. Is possible this was another side-effect of bug 183286, which was fixed in 3.3.
